awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Uncovering the Physical Mechanism behind Flow Boiling Critical Heat Flux
awd_abstract_narration:
Many industries including those in energy, aerospace, defense, and consumer electronics sectors are seeing a significant increase in energy utilization. Current cooling systems that use air or water flows are often incapable of extracting the heat effectively and maintaining reasonable operating temperatures. Boiling of liquids is a very effective cooling mechanism, but there is a limit on how much boiling systems can extract, defined by the critical heat flux. Exceeding the critical heat flux can cause a failure of the heat-generating system or device. The overarching goal of this project is the understand the physics behind the critical heat flux.  This understanding can then be used to to avoid failure in boiling systems. The educational and outreach goal for the project is to complement the research activity by developing a module for Case Western Reserve University’s “Introduction to Innovation” program, the centerpiece of a new campus-wide broader impact strategy, to give middle school educators experience in applying core scientific concepts to understanding simple cooling systems. A lab demonstration of the pool boiling phenomena has been planned to supplement the teaching section of the module to focus on phase-transformation due to boiling in natural systems.

It has been shown that flow boiling critical heat flux can be triggered by hydrodynamic liquid-vapor instabilities occurring in the flow. However, to date, no thorough validation of the phenomena has been performed to ascertain the mechanism behind it. In this project, the investigators plan to develop a fundamental understanding of the mechanism behind critical heat flux by exploring interfacial flow dynamics during flow boiling by using a combination of high-speed imaging and particle image velocimetry measurements. Using the data obtained, a mechanistic model will be developed to predict critical heat flux.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigated the development of a new mechanistic model for predicting an important performance parameter in flow boiling thermal management systems, critical heat flux (CHF). We tested a hypothesis that CHF in flow boiling is triggered by hydrodynamic liquid-vapor instabilities occurring in the direction of fluid flow and perpendicular to the heated wall. We explored interfacial flow dynamics during flow boiling by performing ground tests and supplementing with high-speed imaging and particle image velocimetry (PIV) to develop a mechanistic understanding of the CHF mechanism.

Intellectual Merits

Critical experiments were performed to understand the impact of orientation on flow boiling. We obtained high-resolution flow visualization image data and PIV data that we used to capture the underlying physics behind the CHF mechanism in addition to data on heat transfer and pressure drops in mini-channels. While we could not fully validate the hypothesis, we confirmed better predicting capability based on the mechanism stated in the hypothesis. The work also led to the development of a mechanistic model to predict flow boiling CHF. The proposed model provided an effective means of predicting the CHF phenomena in a highly efficient and accurate way. Another important impact was that the improved understanding of liquid-vapor instabilities is applicable to not only flow boiling in mini-channels scenarios but other phase-change systems including flow boiling and condensation at micro-macro scales impacting designs for full two-phase systems.

Broader Impacts

The work impacts development of two-phase systems utilizing flow boiling that have the ability to provide 1-2 orders of magnitude improvement in thermal performance over current single-phase counterparts, directly increasing total energy savings. Utilization boiling schemes improve efficiency in power generation with renewable energy technologies like solar, wind and nuclear, and also contribute to increasing water conservation and storage in traditional power plant technologies. The overall technology transitions possible in the renewable space and water conservation space would also result in a direct reduction in greenhouse emissions. The mechanistic CHF model we developed will help thermal design engineers develop safe flow boiling configurations for these industries. It will help them transition to more widespread implementation of two-phase thermal management systems utilizing flow boiling as the cooling scheme. The PI’s educational and outreach goal included developing a module for CWRU’s “Introduction to Innovation” program, and he provided a 2-hour teaching module to a group of 8 primary school educators in applying core scientific concepts to understanding simple two-phase devices. A lab demonstration of the pool boiling phenomena was conducted and demonstrated by PI Kharangate as part of the module.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Chirag Kharangate
